articles.headline: The Screen on a Laptop Wants to Be a Tablet
articles.snippet: The ATIV Smart PC Pro 700T from Samsung has the Microsoft Surface Pro’s speed, but comes up short in other ways.
articles.abstract: The ATIV Smart PC Pro 700T from Samsung has the Microsoft Surface Pro’s speed, but comes up short in other ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s admit it: Love it or hate it, Windows 8 was designed for touch screens. Its new facade, the colorful quilt of square tiles that I call TileWorld, was born for finger operation.

articles.headline: Euro Zone Crisis Has Increased I.M.F.’s Power
articles.snippet: Christine Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has become as influential as a head of state in Europe, causing controversy both inside and outside the region.
articles.abstract: Christine Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has become as influential as a head of state in Europe, causing controversy both inside and outside the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — When Wolfgang Schäuble, the German finance minister and war horse of European politics, celebrated his 70th birthday at a theater in Berlin last September, two of the most powerful women in the world offered warm words in his honor.

articles.headline: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
articles.snippet: Scrubbing your profile from a social networking site isn’t easy; more users make the site look better to advertisers. Here are some tools to make the break.
articles.abstract: Scrubbing your profile from a social networking site isn’t easy; more users make the site look better to advertisers. Here are some tools to make the break.

articles.headline: Rising Bank Profits Tempt a Push for Tougher Rules
articles.snippet: Steady earnings growth on Wall Street could embolden the lawmakers and regulators who want to overhaul the banking system.
articles.abstract: Steady earnings growth on Wall Street could embolden the lawmakers and regulators who want to overhaul the banking system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks have been reporting steady growth in earnings since soon after the financial crisis. With the latest reports rolling in, analysts think the banks’ first-quarter profits will be their best ever.

articles.headline: More Children in Greece Are Going Hungry
articles.snippet: Greece’s economic free fall is reshaping the lives of families with children, many of whom arrive at school hungry, underfed or even malnourished.
articles.abstract: Greece’s economic free fall is reshaping the lives of families with children, many of whom arrive at school hungry, underfed or even malnourished.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As an elementary school principal, Leonidas Nikas is used to seeing children play, laugh and dream about the future. But recently he has seen something altogether different, something he thought was impossible in Greece: children picking through school trash cans for food; needy youngsters asking playmates for leftovers; and an 11-year-old boy, Pantelis Petrakis, bent over with hunger pains.

articles.headline: News Media Weigh Use of Photos of Carnage
articles.snippet: Pictures of the aftermath of the bombings at the Boston Marathon started a debate among news organizations about when images are too horrifying to display.
articles.abstract: Pictures of the aftermath of the bombings at the Boston Marathon started a debate among news organizations about when images are too horrifying to display.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even for a society comfortable with blood and gore in its movies and video games, the bombings at the Boston Marathon have sparked a new debate among news organizations about when images are too gruesome to display.

articles.headline: U.S. Accuses Company of Adding Mobile Fees
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission announced its first mobile cramming case, accusing a company of taking advantage of consumers by tacking unwarranted charges onto their phone bills.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission announced its first mobile cramming case, accusing a company of taking advantage of consumers by tacking unwarranted charges onto their phone bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Those surreptitious charges for flirting tips, yoga lessons and psychic services, long a problem on landlines, have become a costly nuisance for mobile phone users — and a new focus for regulators.

articles.headline: Gun Control Effort Had No Real Chance, Despite Pleas
articles.snippet: The defeat of several measures in the Senate made it clear that while the national sentiment about stemming the menace of guns in the wrong hands has shifted, the political dynamic has not.
articles.abstract: The defeat of several measures in the Senate made it clear that while the national sentiment about stemming the menace of guns in the wrong hands has shifted, the political dynamic has not.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, his face set with rage, stood in the Rose Garden surrounded by the families of Newtown and former Representative Gabrielle Giffords and asked how a measure to expand background checks for gun buyers — one supported by an overwhelming majority of Americans and a bipartisan majority of the Senate — had slipped away.

articles.headline: Plant Explosion Tears at the Heart of a Texas Town
articles.snippet: A day after a blast in West, Tex., so powerful it registered as an earthquake, the cause was unclear but the effects — as many as 15 dead, up to 180 hurt and much of a town gone — were plain.
articles.abstract: A day after a blast in West, Tex., so powerful it registered as an earthquake, the cause was unclear but the effects — as many as 15 dead, up to 180 hurt and much of a town gone — were plain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST, Tex. — The blast was so powerful that the United States Geological Survey registered it as a 2.1-magnitude earthquake. It reduced an apartment complex to a charred skeleton, leveled homes in a five-block radius and burned with such intensity that railroad tracks were fused. It killed up to 15 people and injured up to 180. Volunteer firefighters were missing. Residents of a nursing home were pulled from debris and rushed to hospitals.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and John Schwartz

articles.headline: F.B.I. Posts Images of Pair Suspected in Boston Attack
articles.snippet: After the agency released images of two men wanted in the Boston bombings, the calls began flooding in.
articles.abstract: After the agency released images of two men wanted in the Boston bombings, the calls began flooding in.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In a direct appeal for help from the public, the F.B.I. on Thursday released pictures and video of two young men who officials believe may be responsible for the explosions that killed three people and wounded more than 170 during the Boston Marathon.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye, Michael Cooper and Michael S. Schmidt
